body:
Last year ago there was the nether update - which created an entire new aspect to the game. At the least it could be considered an ok update and at the best it could be considered a great one. A year has passed without any updates - and the update to soon be given is essentially nothing. The hype for a cave update has been greatly disappointed. It may not be until Christmas until what will by then be considered a moderate update is given. 
The game is perhaps the most popular that has existed. It might have not been even supposed to be still alive. It was dying. And then Swedish man - yes Swedish man and Swedish man alone. He was the one who made flappy bird popular - his influence is undeniable. And later on there was dream - who also gave a huge boost to the game. I don’t think it will see such growth ever again.

The game is perhaps the most popular that has existed. It might have not been even supposed to be still alive. It was dying. And then Swedish man - yes Swedish man and Swedish man alone. He was the one who made flappy bird popular - his influence is undeniable. And later on there was dream - who also gave a huge boost to the game. I don’t think it will see such growth ever again.

author.bio: See you on the other side

body: In all honesty, if you're looking for solid new content, modding is the way to go. The amount of quality content from mods like The Aether, Twilight Forest, Tinker's Construct, Quark, etc is incredible, to the point where choosing to play older versions of minecraft for the sake of the mods they can run feels like an upgrade rather than a sacrifice. With regards to your point about the popularity of the game, I think you're right about the game peaking in popularity for now, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. People like Dream and Pewdiepie brought the game back into the spotlight, but there's always been a community of people that sticks by the game just for the fun of it, no matter how it's faring with YouTube's algorithm. The folks from Hermitcraft come to mind. TL;DR, don't worry too much about Mojang or popular Youtubers, more often than not the community can supply what they can't or won't. There are certainly things to worry about, like the kerfuffle with Microsoft account migration, but I doubt we'll see minecraft truly die off for a good long time.

The amount of quality content from mods like The Aether, Twilight Forest, Tinker's Construct, Quark, etc is incredible, to the point where choosing to play older versions of minecraft for the sake of the mods they can run feels like an upgrade rather than a sacrifice. With regards to your point about the popularity of the game, I think you're right about the game peaking in popularity for now, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. People like Dream and Pewdiepie brought the game back into the spotlight, but there's always been a community of people that sticks by the game just for the fun of it, no matter how it's faring with YouTube's algorithm. The folks from Hermitcraft come to mind. TL;DR, don't worry too much about Mojang or popular Youtubers, more often than not the community can supply what they can't or won't. There are certainly things to worry about, like the kerfuffle with Microsoft account migration, but I doubt we'll see minecraft truly die off for a good long time.

body: Basically what happened was YouTube was like "NOOOOOOOOOOOOO Minecraft videos aren't as popular anymore, we're losing so much monies!" so they hired people like Dream to make click-baity videos about it and the algorithm would promote them everywhere they could. It worked, and now they have huge stanbases of children and people attracted to them who are so immature that they will "cancel" anyone who doesn't worship them.

body: Because the new versions kinda suck, let's be honest. They're all targeted at 5-year-olds who will go crazy over every new feature and really it's just weird modpacks at this point. It's been a bit off all the way since 2011 even but it REALLY picked up with 1.9+.

The amount of quality content from mods like The Aether, Twilight Forest, Tinker's Construct, Quark, etc is incredible, to the point where choosing to play older versions of minecraft for the sake of the mods they can run feels like an upgrade rather than a sacrifice. With regards to your point about the popularity of the game, I think you're right about the game peaking in popularity for now, but that's not necessarily a bad thing. People like Dream and Pewdiepie brought the game back into the spotlight, but there's always been a community of people that sticks by the game just for the fun of it, no matter how it's faring with YouTube's algorithm. There are certainly things to worry about, like the kerfuffle with Microsoft account migration, but I doubt we'll see minecraft truly die off for a good long time.
